turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about BBC Three (online).
turn.1: What programs were broadcast on BBC Three?
turn.2: The initial slate of new programs to debut through BBC Three included the "Doctor Who" spin-off "Class" (which was cancelled after a single series), the new dramas "Clique" and "Thirteen", "Live from the BBC", a stand-up comedy series focusing on up and coming comedians; the three-part web series " The Man Who Witnessed 219 Executions"; and "Unsolved: The Boy Who Disappeared".
turn.3: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: Promoted as being a British equivalent to the web series "Serial", "Unsolved" would feature weekly installments investigating a real-life crime story.
turn.5: What other programs did it broadcast?
turn.6: The service will also produce a series of short films in collaboration with Idris Elba and up and coming talent.
turn.8: With the service's budget cut to £30 million, some of BBC Three's historic staples, such as panel shows, "Don't Tell the Bride", and U.S. animated comedy "Family Guy" were dropped.
turn.9: What happened when it was dropped?
turn.10: Some BBC Three series had already been moved to other outlets in anticipation of the shutdown; "Russell Howard's Good News" was moved to BBC Two in 2014, and "Don't Tell the Bride" was moved to BBC One for a single series before being dropped and acquired by Sky 1.
turn.12: ITV2 acquired rights to new episodes of "Family Guy" and other Seth MacFarlane series in March 2015, although the BBC continued to hold rights to past episodes of "Family Guy" until 2017.
